facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 553 of 1963 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 27, 1963, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Revision Petition No. 476 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 553 of 1963. Appeal, by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 27, 1963, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Revision Petition No. 476 of 1962.

facts.text: Kashibai Sangappa Gadigappa Desai died on January 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: the estate of deceased Kashibai Sangappa Gadigappa Desai who died on the 1st January, 1958. According to this direction, the Administrator has to manage the estate of the said deceased Kashibai including the scheduled property, both movable and immovable, until the right of succession is determined by a companypetent compan

facts.text: Additional District Judge at Bijapur appointed Deputy Commissioner of Bijapur District as administrator for the estate of deceased Kashibai under rule 9 of Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827.

anchor.surface_text: Purporting to act under the said Rule the learned Additional District Judge at Bijapur has ordered that the Dy. Commissioner of Bijapur District be appointed the administrator for the management of the estate of deceased Kashibai Sangappa Gadigappa Desai who died on the 1st January, 1958. According to this direction, the Administrator has to manage the estate of the said deceased Kashibai including the scheduled property, both movable and immovable, until the right of succession is determined by a companypetent compan

facts.text: Appellant Mallappa Basappa Desai challenged the appointment order in Mysore High Court under section 115 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: rt of law. The appellant Mallappa Basappa Desai challenged the propriety and the validity of this order by moving the Mysore High Court in its revisional jurisdiction under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The High Court was, however, satisfied that there was numberground to interfere with the order passed by the learned Additional District Judge.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed the revision petition on February 27, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 553 of 1963. Appeal, by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 27, 1963, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Revision Petition No. 476 of 1962. C. Agarwal, R. K. Garg, D. P. Singh, M. K. Ramamurthi, A. Shankar Alva and M. Veerappa, for the appellants Nos. 1, 3 and 4.

facts.text: Sangappa Gadigappa Desai was the last male holder of the Desgat properties.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the only question which we have to decide in the present case is about the companystruction of r. 9. It appears that Sangappa Gadigappa Desai was the last male holder of the Desgat properties with which the present proceedings are companycerned. These properties are extensive and yield substantial income.

facts.text: Kashibai, widow of Sangappa, came into possession of the properties after his death.

anchor.surface_text: On his death. his widow Kashibai came into possession of the said properties. The appellant alleges that in 1929 the Collector of the district held that the appellants father was the nearest male reversioner to the estate left by Sargappa Desai.

facts.text: Appellant's father died in 1943.

anchor.surface_text: In 1943, the appellants father died. In 1946 again an enquiry was held and it is alleged by the appellant that he was found to be the eldest male member of the eldest branch of the family and as such was entitled to succeed to the Desgat and other properties left by Sangappa.

facts.text: In 1946, an enquiry held and appellant found to be entitled to succeed as eldest male member.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 again an enquiry was held and it is alleged by the appellant that he was found to be the eldest male member of the eldest branch of the family and as such was entitled to succeed to the Desgat and other properties left by Sangappa. Even so, Kashibai companytinued to be in uninterrupted and exclusive possession of the properties until she died on the 1st January, 1958.

facts.text: Kashibai continued in uninterrupted and exclusive possession until her death on January 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, Kashibai companytinued to be in uninterrupted and exclusive possession of the properties until she died on the 1st January, 1958. On the 7th January, 1958, the appellant filed an application before the Mamlatdar praying that his name should be entered in the Record of Rights in respect of- lands of the Jainapur Desgat estate.

facts.text: On January 7, 1958, appellant filed application before Mamlatdar for entry of his name in Record of Rights for lands of Jainapur Desgat estate.

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th January, 1958, the appellant filed an application before the Mamlatdar praying that his name should be entered in the Record of Rights in respect of- lands of the Jainapur Desgat estate. This application led to several other applications by different persons who claimed to be entitled to succeed to the estate.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed Application No. 1 of 1958 under s. 192 of Indian Succession Act on January 8, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: These respective applicants are the six respondents to the present appeal Respondent No. 1 filed Application No. 1 of 1958 under s. 192 of the Indian Succes- siion Act, 1925, on the 8th January, 1958. On the same day, respondent No. 1 applied for the appointment of a Commissioner and an ex parte order was passed appointing Mr. Managoli as the Commissioner.

facts.text: On January 8, 1958, ex parte order appointed Mr. Managoli as Commissioner, inventory made, later confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, respondent No. 1 applied for the appointment of a Commissioner and an ex parte order was passed appointing Mr. Managoli as the Commissioner. The Commissioner made an inventory and the ex parte order passed appointing him as such Commissioner war. later companyfirmed.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 filed Application No. 2 under Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827 on January 9, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th January, 1958, respondent No. 2 filed Application No. 2 under Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827. On the 5th February, 1958, respondents 3 4 filed Application No. 4/1958 under rules 9 10 of the said Regulation.

facts.text: Respondents 3 and 4 filed Application No. 4/1958 under rules 9 and 10 of Regulation on February 5, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On the 5th February, 1958, respondents 3 4 filed Application No. 4/1958 under rules 9 10 of the said Regulation. On the 6th February 1.958, respondent No. 2 filed Application No. 511958 under s. 192 of the Indian Succession Act.

facts.text: Tehsildar ordered on February 27, 1958, that appellant's name be shown as superior holder in Record of Rights for Desgat estate lands.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the application made by the appellant for mutation of his name in the Record of Rights the Tehsildar made an order on the 27th February, 1958 directing that the appellants name should be shown as superior holder in respect of the lands forming part of the Desgat estate.

facts.text: Respondents 1 to 4 appealed Tehsildar's order to Assistant Commissioner of Bijapur, appeals dismissed on May 17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: That order was challenged by respondents 1 to 4 by appeals preferred before the Assistant Commissioner of Bijapur. Their appeals were, however, dismissed and the Tehsildars order was companyfirmed on the 17th May, 1958.

facts.text: Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal allowed revisions by respondents on December 5, 1958, directing names of respondents entered as superior holders along with appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The said respondents then moved the Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal in its revisional jurisdiction. The Appellate Tribunal allowed the revision applications by its order dated 5th December, 1958 and directed that the names of the respondents should be ,entered as superior holders along with the appellant.

facts.text: Mysore High Court under Art. 227 allowed appellant's application on December 7, 1959, set aside Tribunal order, confirmed Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the Mysore High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution and his application was allowed, the order passed by the Appellate Tribunal was set aside and that of the Assistant Commissioner was companyfirmed. This decision was pronounced on the 7th December, 1959.

facts.text: Additional District Judge on January 18, 1960, appointed administrator under r.9.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th January, 1960, the Additional District Judge who heard the several applications made before him by respon- dents 1 to 6, came to the companyclusion that a case had been made out for the appointment of an Administrator to the property in question under r. 9 of the Regulation and accordingly, he made the order which is the subject-matter of the present appeal.

facts.text: Additional District Judge found dispute as to succession to Kashibai's estate, several persons applied with claims.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the question of the companystruction of rule 9, it is necessary to set out the facts found by the learned Additional District Judge in the present proceedings. He has found that there is a dispute as to the succession to the estate left by the deceased Kashibai in fact, several persons have applied setting forth their respective, claims to succeed to the said estate.

facts.text: Additional District Judge found no person amongst parties had taken possession of the estate.

anchor.surface_text: He has also found that there is numberperson amongst the parties before him who can be said to have taken possession of the estate. In other words, according to the learned Judge, a dispute exists in regard to the estate between two or more claimants and numbere of them has taken possession of the estate.

facts.text: Appellant claimed possession of substantial part of immovable agricultural lands via rent notes by tenants.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before him on behalf ,of the appellant that a substantial part of the immovable property companysisting of agricultural lands was in his possession, and reliance was placed in that behalf on the rent numberes executed by the tenants who were cultivating the said lands.

facts.text: Additional District Judge held rent notes executed subsequent to commencement of proceedings, did not help appellant, affected by lis pendens.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge held that these documents had companye into existence subsequent to the companymencement of the proceedings before him, and so, they did number help the appellant. He also seems to have taken the view that these rent numberes would be affected by lis pendens.

facts.text: Movable property was in custody of the Court; Commissioner appointed, inventory made, then taken into Court possession.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the movables, it is number disputed that the said movable property was in the custody of the Court. A Commissioner had been appointed to make inventory of the said properties and after the inventory had been made, they were taken into the possession of the Court.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1 authorised the legal heir, executor, or legal administrator to assume the management, or sue for the recovery, of the property

That is how the only question which we have to decide in the present case is about the construction of r. 9.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: aside the order appointing the administrator, because at the date when the High Court is passing the order one of the claimants has secured possessio

holdings.text: What the Court has to consider in dealing with the question of possession is was any of the claimants in possession of the properties succession to which is in dispute at the date of the commencement of the proceedings under this Regulation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of rule 9 clause requires possession assessed at commencement to effectuate summary purpose from preamble, avoid anomalies like interim possession altering outcome on appeal

holdings.text: we are satisfied that the Courts below were right in holding that since the appellant was not in possession at the date when the present proceedings commenced and obviously there is a dispute as to the title between two or more claimants, the material requirement of r. 9 is satisfied and that justifies the appointment of an administrator
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies rule 9 to undisputed dispute (f21) and accepted fact of no possession at commencement (f22-f24 accepted, post-commencement evidence irrelevant per h1)

holdings.text: Rules 8 and 9 both make it clear that the decision recorded by the Court under the provisions of the relevant Rules is a summary decision and it does not purport to bar the jurisdiction of the civil courts by which questions of title would be finally determined
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of rules 8 (refusal not final) and 9 supports snapshot possession check at commencement without final title adjudication

holdings.text: under the relevant clause of r. 9, the date of possession must be the date before the proceedings commenced
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects date-of-order view (a7) as inconsistent with summary nature (h3) and policy for prompt administration where no early possession post-death

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that the Courts below were right in holding that since the appellant was number in possession at the date when the present proceedings companymenced and obviously there is a dispute as to the title between two or more claimants, the material requirement of r. 9 is satisfied and that justifies the appointment of an administrator.

outcome.relief_summary: Appointment of administrator under rule 9 of Bombay Regulation VIII of 1827 upheld as justified; lower courts' findings affirmed
